As part of a plan to modernize the institution, MoMA signed a ten-year lease with the Spanish firm Andrés Pedraza in 2016, and in early 2019, the artist’s sculptures were removed from display. “Marcos’s work was never installed at the Met, and after his removal, the sculpture was never exhibited in a public setting,” the museum said in a statement. “This is a difficult situation for all of us, and we are all deeply disappointed that these sculptures were never displayed at the Met, and that they remain in storage.”Pedraza received the three Marcos sculptures—Aguilar, Pena, and Maricela—from the artist during the construction of a new building adjacent to MoMA that will be completed in 2021.
